titlestmt.titleproper: Romanowitz, Byron F. collection on jazz in Lexington, Kentucky
Guide to the Byron F. Romanowitz collection on jazz in Lexington, Kentucky, 1940-2016, undated 2016ms013
titlestmt.author: Logan McGuire

publicationstmt.publisher: University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-05-03 15:32:38 -0400.

repository.corpname: University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center

did.unittitle: Byron F. Romanowitz collection on jazz in Lexington, Kentucky
did.abstract: The Byron F. Romanowitz collection on jazz in Lexington, Kentucky (dated 1940-2016, undated; 2.25 cubic feet; 3 boxes) comprises photographs, documents, and audio recordings relating to the Jazz artist Byron F. Romanowitz and his various musical groups in central Kentucky.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged in seven series by format: Audio recordings, Biographical information, Jazzberry Jam, Lexington Views, Men of Note, Personal papers, and Photographs.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Byron Foster Romanowitz received a Bachelor's degree in Civil Engineering from the University of Kentucky in 1951 acting as a member of a number of honor societies and a social fraternity. He went on to graduate from Princeton University in 1954 with a Master's degree in Architecture. His time at the school was highlighted by his experience as a part time instructor in undergraduate architectural design, as well as his involvement as the leader of the jazz combo The Princetonians. Byron looked to further his education more, pursuing a Ph.D. as well, but was interrupted by his service in the United States Naval Reserve Civil Engineering Corps as a Lieutenant Commander, constructing buildings and airfields. Throughout his life Byron followed his passion for music and jazz, playing the tenor saxophone with a variety of combos and groups at a multitude of venues. A registered architect and engineer, Romanowitz was once the president of Johnson Romanowitz Architects and Planners, a large architectural firm in Lexington, Kentucky. The firm took on jobs for a number of prominent buildings throughout the central Kentucky area including Rupp Arena, the Louisville Free Public Library, as well as some on both the University of Kentucky and University of Louisville campuses.

Men of Note a group originally started by hobbiest jazz players, was an popular ensamble in the central Kentucky area. Playing a variety of public and private events, the group was often sought after for their jazz performances from the 1960s into the early aughts.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 2016ms013: [identification of item], Byron F. Romanowitz collection on jazz in Lexington, Kentucky, 1940-2016, undated, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Byron F. Romanowitz collection on jazz in Lexington, Kentucky (dated 1940-2016, undated; 2.25 cubic feet; 3 boxes) comprises photographs, documents, and audio recordings relating to the Jazz artist Byron F. Romanowitz and his various musical groups in central Kentucky. Much of the collection pertains to his time in the groups Men of Note and Jazzberry Jam. Also included are news articles concerning Romanowitz and his musical groups, photographs from various events and performances, as well as messages sent to and from Romanowitz. The collection does contain a small amount of personal papers as well as files documenting his editorials in the Lexington Herald-Leader.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to these materials belong to the University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center.

did.unittitle: Audio recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Th Audio recordings series (dated 1940-2009, undated) contains sound recordings of perfomances by Byron F. Romanowitz throughout his musical career. Group performances include Romanowitz playing with the Charles Blair band, Men of Note, the Dave Parry Orchestra, and others. Recordings are from a wide number of locations, such as the Narcotics Farm and the Coach House Lounge, both in Lexington, Kentucky.

Biographical information

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Biographical information series (dated 1950-2016, undated) contains biographical information on artists known by Byron F. Romanowitz, frequently those with whom he had performed. Primarily the series includes correspondence between the artists as well as various publications about the musicians.

Jazzberry Jam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Jazzberry Jam series (dated 1992-2015, undated) contains files detailing the members and performances by the jazz group. Jazzberry Jam is the name of the group created by Byron F. Romanowitz following his retirement. This musical group allowed him to continue pursuing his passion for jazz music and performing.

Performance paperwork and correspondence
Performance contracts
Performance contracts
Images and vocalists
Promotional material and group information
Service mark and trademark forms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Lexington Views series (dated 1994-1996) contains monthly issues of the local Lexington, Kentucky news magazine. Most issues include editorials and articles written by Byron Ramanowitz on topics like regional architecture, local events, and music.

did.unittitle: Men of Note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Men of Note series (dated 1979-2016, undated) contains documents pertaining to the band's recordings and concerts. Included in the series are two compact disks with files about the concerts and music arrangements. The series also contains performace recordings and concert ephemera.

did.unittitle: Compact Disk information
Compact Disk information and charts
General information
Performances and cassette tape charts
Tribute concert and Headley Whitney concert
Personal papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Personal papers series (dated 1940-2016, undated) contains correspondence, documents, and writings rom the personal life of Byron F. Romanowitz. The documents provide insight into the mind of the musician, comprising letters to editors, clippings, as well as writings to friends and bandmates.

Public statements and writings by Bryron F. Romanowitz
R.L. Sanders and the Blue and White Orchestra History
Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Photographs series (dated 1940-2011, undated) comprise photographs of jazz band performances primarily in Lexington, Kentucky. Most of the photographs depict Men of Note members at various concerts. The series also includes some early Lexington jazz band ensembles and Byron F. Romanowitz as a young musician in school bands.
